ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Graphene layer number dependent size distribution of silver nanoparticles

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We observe that silver atoms deposited by thermal evaporation deposition onto n-layer graphene films condense upon annealing to form nanoparticles with an average diameter and density that is determined by the layer numbers of graphene films. The optical microscopy and Raman spectroscopy were utilized to identify the number of the graphene layers and the SEM (scanning electron microscopy) was used to observe the morphologies of the particles. Systematic analysis revealed that the average sizes of the nanoparticles increased with the number of graphene layers. The density of nanoparticles decreased as the number of graphene layers increased, revealing a large variation in the surface diffusion strength of nanoparticles on the different substrates. The mechanisms of formation of these layer-dependent morphologies of silver nanoparticles are related to the surface free energy and surface diffusion of the n-layer graphenes.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para:
Graphene is attracting intense interest due to its distinctive band structure and many outstanding properties, which hold exciting promise for electronic applications. A single atomic layer of graphene is the thinnest sp
$$^{2}$$
2
allotrope of carbon which has attracted immense attention since the first demonstration of reliable methods to rapidly isolate and identify it [1â3]. It, therefore, has various unique electrical and optical properties of interest to scientists and technologists [4â7]. The graphene samples are widely fabricated by the micromechanical cleavage of highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) with scotch tape. The number of graphene layers was determined by cross-corroboration between an interference-induced optical contrast in an optical microscope [8â11].

The Raman measurement has been widely used as powerful techniques for characterizing the phonons of grapheme. The profile and peak position of the Raman second-order (2D) band can be used to determine the number of graphene layers [8, 12]. The few-layer graphenes have attracted intense interest due to their unique structure and significant dependence of properties on the layer number [2, 3]. For example, with different layer number of graphene, the carriers correspond to massless and massive Dirac fermions and the quantum hall effect occurs at different filling factors [13, 14].

In this work, layers of graphene were fabricated by micromechanical cleavage. The silver nanoparticles were deposited on the sample using a thermal deposition system. The number of layers of graphene was determined by optical microscopy and micro-Raman spectroscopy. The distributions and sizes of the particles on graphene flakes with different numbers of graphene layers were systematically analyzed. The different results for the few-layer graphenes are theorized to be caused by the variation among the diffusion barriers of the various graphene layers, which provide the information that can be utilized to elucidate the interaction between a graphene flake and sample substrate and provide a method of determining the number of graphene layers.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para: To study the surface diffusion of n-layer graphenes, silver nanoparticles were evaporated onto the sample surface in a vacuum thermal evaporator at a deposition rate of 10Â Ã /s to a thickness of 5Â nm at a fixed temperature of the deposition system of 300Â K and the sample was maintained at 373Â K in a vacuum for 1Â h. The morphology of the sample surface as well as the size and density of silver nanoparticles were studied in detail by SEM.

The inset of Fig.Â 2aâd respectively shows the SEM image of distribution of nanoparticles on the mono-, bi-, tri-, and four layer graphene. The distribution of silver nanoparticles on n-layer graphenes are closely related to the layer number. The grain sizes of silver nanoparticles are larger for the silver nanoparticles on the multi-layer graphene as compared to those on the monolayer graphene. The density of nanoparticles decreased as the number of graphene layer increased.

The mechanisms of layer number dependent morphologies of silver nanoparticles on graphenes are related to thermodynamic (e.g., energetics and stability) and kinetic (e.g., surface diffusion) factors. One possible reason may be that the surface free energy of n-layer graphenes is dependent on the layer number. Different morphologies of silver nanoparticles on the different layered graphene flakes are obtained when silver particles are deposited on the graphene surfaces because of the differences of surface free energy. The variation in surface free energy with the graphene layer number is responsible for the variation in the morphologies of deposited silver nanoparticles. Another possible reason can be attributed to the surface diffusion. When silver atoms are deposited on the graphene surface, the arriving atoms may form a new island with other atoms (nucleation) or walk into an existing one (growth). The diffusion coefficient determines the outcome of the nucleation, growth, and the density of deposited silver nanoparticles [15, 16]. The particles are randomly deposited on the graphene surface, and surface diffusion causes randomly arranged particles to combine and to form relatively large particle islands. A large diffusion coefficient means a high probability for an arriving atom to find an existing island, yielding a low number of islands after deposition. Therefore, different surface diffusion coefficients can result in layer-dependent morphologies, grain sizes, and densities of silver nanoparticles on n-layer graphenes.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In this work, the distribution and the grain sizes of silver nanoparticles on flakes with different number graphene layers were systematically analyzed. The results reveal that the increasing layer number of graphene will result in the rising average size of nanoparticles, the decreasing density of distributed nanoparticles, and lowering the difference between the diffusion barriers of nanoparticles. The mechanisms of graphene layer number dependent morphologies of silver nanoparticles are related to the surface free energy and surface diffusion of the n-layer graphenes. Different results for the few-layer graphenes are theorized to be caused by the variation among the diffusion barriers of various graphene layers, which provides information that can be utilized to elucidate the interaction between a graphene flake and a sample substrate, and provides a method for determining the number of graphene layers.
